caseName: State v. Weekly
caseNameFull: The State of Ohio, Appellee, v. Weekly, Appellant
judge: Zimmerman, Weygandt, Bell, Williams, Matthias, Hart, Turner

opinions.snippet:
Defendant makes only one contention in this court,viz., that he was entitled to a directed verdict of acquittal, pursuant to his motions therefor, because it was not shown that he had committed any statutory offense.
In support of such claim the argument is made that at common law dogs were not regarded as property the stealing of which constituted an offense; that the only manner in which dogs may be raised to the dignity of personal property subject to larceny in Ohio is by

posture:
APPEAL from the Court of Appeals of Wayne county.

Subsequent to preliminary proceedings before a justice of the peace, an indictment was returned by the grand jury of Wayne county in January of 1945 against the defendant, appellant herein, reading as follows:

"One Willard Weekly, on or about the 30th day of August, 1944, at the county of Wayne aforesaid, did unlawfully steal, take and carry away a certain red tick hound dog of the value of $100, the personal property of Everett Etzwiler, contrary to the form of the statute in such case made and provided, and against the peace and dignity of the state of Ohio."

Upon his plea of "not guilty," the defendant was tried before a judge and jury. The jury returned a verdict in the following form:

"We, the jury in this case, duly impanelled and sworn and affirmed, find the defendant Willard Weekly, guilty of grand larceny, in manner and form as he stands charged in the indictment."

An appeal was taken to the Court of Appeals on questions of law. That court reversed the judgment below and remanded the cause, on the sole ground that the jury failed to ascertain and declare in their verdict the value of the property found to have been stolen.

The court relied on Section 13448-3, General Code, which provides:

"When an indictment * * * charges an offense against property by larceny, * * * in case the value
thereof shall determine the degree of the offense, or shall determine the punishment, the jury, on conviction shall ascertain and declare in their verdict the value of such property."

Allowance of the defendant's motion for leave to appeal places the cause before this court for determination on its merits.
